                               JUDGMENT

(02/11/2017) Per S.K.Awasthi, J.

Since both the appeals are connected and arise out of the common judgment dated 03/07/2000, passed by the IIIrd Additional Sessions Judge, Shivpuri, District Shivpuri (MP) in Sessions Trial No. 315/1998, they are decided by 2 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 the present common judgment.

(2) Bharatpuri, Vidyapuri, Kalyan, Mahesh & Kishanpuri, the appellants of Criminal Appeal No.540/2000 have preferred the present appeal being aggrieved with the aforesaid judgment whereby, appellants No. 1 to 4 have been convicted of offences under Sections 148 of IPC and sentenced to 2 years rigorous imprisonment & 302 of IPC read with Section 149 of IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment with fine of Rs.1000/- each, and appellant No.5 has been convicted for the offences under Sections 148 of IPC and sentenced to 2 years rigorous imprisonment & 302 of IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment with fine of Rs. 1000/-, and default sentence has also been prescribed in case of non-payment of fine. (3) The Criminal Appeal No. 389/2001 by the State is against the respondents/accused Naktoo @ Narayanpuri, Kamal @ Kamalpuri, Rameshpuri, Pintu @ Dineshprui & Prahlad being acquitted by the trial Court relating to offences under Sections 148, 323 & 302 or 302/149 of IPC. (4) The facts as unfolded in the judgment impugned are that in the intervening night of 01.09.1998 and 02.09.1998 at about 12.:20 am, a report was lodged at Police Station Kotwali, Shivpuri by the complainant Bharat Singh to the effect that in the evening at about 5:00 pm, when he along with Gajendra, Ram Singh & Omprakash were playing chaupad on the platform of Bharosi Dhakad at village Bakwasakala, at that time accused persons came on the spot. Naktoo, Kamlu, Pintu & Prahlad armed with Saria, Ramesh armed with gun & Bharat, Kishan and Mahesh armed with gandasi came there and surrounded the complainant party. Ramesh Puri with intention to commit murder of Gajendra fired 12 bore gun, but the fire 3 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 was missed. Naktoo assaulted on the head of Gajendra by saria, Kishan assaulted on the head of Gajendra by sword and Mahesh also caused injury on the right hand's elbow of Ganjendra by means of sword. Accused Vidyapuri caused injuries to Ganjendra by gandasi in his right forearm. When Ram Singh and Om Prakash tried to rescue then accused Bharat, Kishan and Vidya caused injury to them by sword and gandasi. As a result of the injuries caused to Ganjendra, he died on the spot. On making alarm, Mantha, Jagdish, Chandrabhan and Sarvan rushed towards the place of occurrence and on seeing them, the accused persons fled from the spot. Thereafter, they took the injured persons Ram Singh, Omprakash & the dead body of deceased Gajendra in the tractor trolley to Police Station Pohari for lodging the FIR, but the in-charge of Police Station did not lodge the report, then they rushed to Police Station Kotwali Shivpuri and submitted an application (Exhibit P-1), on that basis, a case was lodged warranting investigation for the offences punishable under Sections 147, 148, 323, 302 read with Section 149 of IPC. The injured and deceased were sent for medical examination. Later on, as the incident was within the jurisdiction of Police Station Pohari, hence the FIR was sent to above Police Station, where the original case was registered as FIR (Exhibit P-35). Upon conclusion of the investigation, the charge-sheet was filed to the Court of Judicial Magistrate First Class, Pohari, district Shivpuri, who committed the case to the Court of Sessions and ultimately it was transferred to IIIrd Additional Session Judge, Shivpuri.

(5) After hearing counsel for the parties, the Sessions Court framed the charges for the offences 4 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 punishable under Sections 148, 302 read with Section 149, 323 or 323/149 and Section 25/27 of the Arms Act against accused Rameshpuri; under Sections 148, 302, 323 and 323/149 of IPC against the accused Kalyan, Vidyapuri, Maheshpuri, Naktoo & Kishanpuri, whereas charges under Sections 148, 302/149, 323 or 323/149 of IPC were framed against the accused Prahlad, Kamalpuri, Bharatpuri & Pintoo @ Dinesh. On denial of charges, the trial commenced as desired.

(6) To prove the charges as framed against the accused persons, the prosecution examined 19 witnesses. After completion of prosecution evidence, the accused persons were examined under Section 313 of Cr.P.C. (7) The accused persons took a plea that they are innocent and have been falsely implicated in the matter. In the defence, they examined 4 witnesses, namely, Bharosi (DW/1), Ramdayal Verma (DW/2), Shankarlal Shrivastava (DW/3) and Gopalkrishna Trivedi (DW/4). (8) The trial Court after considering the evidence adduced by the parties concluded that the prosecution has failed to make out a case against Naktoo, Kamal @ Kamalpuri, Rameshpuri, Pintoo @ Dinesh and Prahlad, and therefore, they were acquitted, however, observed that there is overwhelming evidence against the appellants Kishanpuri, Mahesh, Bharatpuri, Vidyapuri & Kalyan, therefore, conviction was recorded against them for the offences punishable under Sections 148 & 302 of IPC. Hence, the present appeals.

(9) Learned counsel for the accused/appellants while arguing for setting aside the order of conviction and sentence, as impugned herein, contended that conviction of the appellants/accused is based on surmises and 5 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 conjectures. It is contended that the prosecution has utterly failed in proving the guilt against appellants beyond reasonable doubt. Thus, there is no cogent evidence to fasten the guilt over the appellants. The First Information Report was lodged after a delay of 7 hours of the incident and there is no explanation for such delay in lodging the FIR. It is urged that there are material contradictions and improvements in the testimony of prosecution witnesses. No independent witness supported the prosecution case. In the statement of Bharat Singh (PW-1), he stated that there was enmity between the parties and on the report of accused Narayanpuri, a case was also registered against the complainant under Section 307 of IPC and the same is pending in the Court, thus, there is every possibility of implicating the present appellants in a false and fabricated case. On these contentions, learned counsel for the appellants seek quashment of order of conviction and seek acquittal. (10) Learned counsel for the State supported the judgment of conviction and sentence passed by the trial Court against the appellants/accused and submitted that the same does not call for any interference. He further submitted that the trial Court has committed error by acquitting the respondents/accused. There exist overwhelming evidence against the respondents/accused. Therefore, finding of acquittal recorded in favour of respondents/accused deserves to be set-aside. The trial Court has concluded in paragraph 54 of the impugned judgment that after considering the evidence of the prosecution, it is clear that Gajendra Singh died due to the injuries caused by the accused persons, but in spite of that respondents/accused persons have been acquitted by the 6 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 trial Court.

(11) We have heard learned counsel for the parties and perused the record.

(12) At the outset, as regard to the death of Gajendra whether was homicidal, the evidence given by Dr. Nisar Ahemad (PW-6) may be considered, who performed the postmortem on the body of deceased and gave his report (Exhibit P-6). He found following injuries on the dead body of the deceased:

1. I.W. 8Cm x 2 cm bone deep vertically placed above & medial to left ear over the left parietal area. Parietal bone on reflection of skin, Haematoma + 5cm x 2 cm, on reflection of the bone extradural bleeding present & after reflecting the meningeal covering - Hemorrhages over the brain.
2. I.W. 8 cm x bone deep in the center of scalp haematoma underlying the skin present & hemorrhages over the brain.
3. I.W. 8Cm x 2 cm muscle deep over base of index finger 7cm ant side to posterior.
4. I.W. 9Cm x 2 cm transversely placed over right palm from below right ring finger to base of the thumb muscle deep.
5. I.W. 5Cm x 3 cm bone deep above lateral to right patella lower end of the femur lat. asp. cut.
6. I.W. 2 cm x 2 cm muscle deep above injury No. 5.
7. I.W. 3cm x 1 cm above injury No. 6 lower part of thigh.
8. I.W. 1cm x 1/2 cm muscle deep present over antrolat. part of middle 1/3 of right leg.
7

9. I.W. 3Cm x 1 cm muscle deep present over antrolat. part of middle 1/3 of right leg.

10. I.W. 1cm x 1/2 cm bone deep antrolat part right leg above right ankle.

11. I.W 1cm x ½ cm bone deep 7 cm above right ankle.

12. I.W 4cm x 2 cm muscle deep ant part right patella.

13. I.W ½ cm x ½ cm muscle deep medial aspect of right lower 1/3 thigh.

14. I.W ½ cm x ½ cm medial aspect left knee joint.

15. I.W ½cm x ½ cm bone deep above injury No.14.

16. I.W. 6cm x 2 cm bone deep over upper part of right scapula.

17. I.W 11cm x ½ cm skin deep obliquely cut over right side back below right scapula.

18. I.W 9cm x ½ cm overlying 17th one, transversely.

19. I.W 10 cm x ½ cm below 18th one.

20. I.W 5cm x 2 cm muscle deep right elbow.

21. I.W 4cm x 2 cm muscle deep right forearm upper 1/3rd posteriorly.

22. Deformity & swelling at the junction of right upper and middle 1/3 of right upper arm.

(13) On the opening of the body of deceased, he found that parietal bone of deceased was broken, meninges were pale and food articles were found on the stomach, digested food was present in the intestine. According to Dr. Nisar Ahemad, the deceased Gajendra died due to head injuries and the injuries found on the 8 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 body of deceased were sufficient to cause his death. (14) Looking to the injuries found on the body of the deceased, those could not be caused in any accident and could not be self inflicted, and therefore, the death of Gajendra Singh was neither accidental nor suicidal, hence it was homicidal in nature.

(15) The prosecution examined Bharat Singh (PW-1), Chandrabhan (PW-2), Mantha (PW-3), Ram Singh (PW-4) & Omprakash (PW-5) as eye witnesses. The FIR (Exhibit P-2) was lodged by Bharat Singh (PW-1) after 7 hours of the incident, whereas the Police Station Kotwali, Shivpuri was 45 kms away from the village Bagwasakala where the incident took place. Bharat Singh (PW-1), Ram Singh (PW-

4) and Omprakash (PW-5) stated in their examination-in- chief that firstly they reached the Police Station-Pohari for lodging the FIR, but after waiting for half an hour when the Police did not lodge the report, they rushed to Police Station Kotwali Shivpuri as the condition of the injured persons was worsening. They submitted a written report and on that basis the FIR (Exhibit P-2) was recorded. Veerendra Singh Tomar (PW-17), the then SHO, Police Station Pohari, stated in his cross-examination that the injured persons firstly reached to the Pohari hospital and after receiving the information, Head Constable went there to record the report, but complainant refused to lodge any report in the hospital by stating that they will lodge the report at Shivpuri. Although, this fact is mentioned in the statements of witnesses-Bharat Singh, Ram Singh & Omprakash Singh recorded under Section 161 of Cr.P.C, but in the cross-examination, they denied the above fact and submitted that they have not given such statement to the Police. The prosecution has not filed any intimation 9 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 received by Police Station Pohari from Civil Hospital Pohari that injured were brought to the hospital and after receiving information, Police went to the Pohari hospital. If such intimation was received by the Police Station Pohari, then it would have recorded in the rojnamcha. The prosecution has not produced any copy of rojnamcha to substantiate this fact. In these circumstances, this possibility cannot be ruled out that to justify the act of non- registration of FIR by the Police, it has been suo moto written by the Police in the statements of witnesses. There is nothing on record which shows that the Head Constable Raja Babu went to the Civil Hospital for recording the FIR, therefore, non-examination of Raja Babu cannot be a ground for rejection of entire prosecution's case. (16) Looking to the distance of the Police Station from the place of occurrence and the circumstances explained by the complainant-Bharat Singh, it cannot be said that the FIR was belated or it is a concocted document.

(17) Learned counsel for the appellants/accused submitted that the prosecution has not complied with the provision of Section 157 (1) of Cr.P.C, and the copy of FIR was not sent to the Judicial Magistrate, however, from perusal of the record, it appears that the copy of the report was sent to the concerned Magistrate on 03.09.1998, which was received on the same day, therefore, we do not find any force in the argument advanced by learned counsel for the appellants/accused in this regard. (18) Bharat Singh (PW-1) stated that accused Kishan gave a blow of sword on head of Gajendra. Chandrabhan (PW/2) deposed that accused Kishan, Bharat & Mahesh were having sword and they inflicted injuries on the head 10 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 and hand of Gajendra Singh. At the time of incident, Kalyan and Vidya were armed with gandasi, whereas the Kamlu was having saria and they caused injuries to the Gajendra. Mantha (PW/3) stated that after hearing some hue and cry, he rushed to the spot where he saw that accused persons were beating deceased Gajendra, but he could not saw that who caused injury on which part of the body of deceased Gajendra.

(19) Ram Singh (PW-4) and Omprakash (PW-5) stated that on 01.09.1998 at about 5:05 pm, they along with Gajendra were playing chaupad on the platform of Bharosi Dhakad, at that time the accused persons came there and surrounded them. The accused Kishan, Bharat and Mahesh were armed with sword, whereas accused Vidya was having gandasi, accused Kamlu was armed with Sariya and with intend to commit murder of Gajendra, they caused injuries to him, as a result of which he died on the spot. (20) The said eye witnesses are no doubt close relatives of the deceased but that by itself cannot be a ground to discard their testimony. It, however, certainly puts this Court on its guard to scrutinize their evidence more carefully, keeping in view their unnatural conduct. The presence of complainant and witnesses along with the deceased has been found proved. Their statements were cogent and consistent and were also corroborated by the medical evidence. The names of appellants/accused were also clearly disclosed in the FIR, Ex. P-2. It is the settled law that conviction can even be based on the sole testimony of an eyewitness provided that testimony is found to be wholly reliable. The appreciation of evidence by the court below is proper and we have not been persuaded to take a different view. Merely because, 5 11 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 other persons named by him as accused were acquitted, would not render their testimony as wholly suspicious because falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is not rule of law accepted by the courts in this country. The Trial court has opined that since the testimony of Prosecution Witnesses Bharat Singh (PW-1), Chandrabhan (PW-2), Mantha (PW-3), Ram Singh (PW-4) & Omprakash (PW-5) had not been supported by the medical evidence insofar as the injuries attributed to the respondents Naktoo @ Narayanpuri, Kamal @ Kamalpuri, Rameshpuri, Pintu @ Dineshprui & Prahlad are concerned, therefore, the benefit of doubt was required to be given to them and they were acquitted.

(21)      The sheet anchor of the argument on behalf of
the       appellants/accused              had          been        the
contradictions/improvements          in     the      statements      of

witnesses, however they are not material and do not go to the root of the cause. Although the eye witnesses have admitted in their cross-examination that they cannot say as to which appellant gave which blow on which part of the body of the deceased, but they have explained the reason that deceased was surrounded by the assailants. Nothing had come in their cross-examination to controvert their statements in respect to the injuries caused to the deceased by the appellant/accused persons, therefore, the statement of the prosecution witnesses have remained intact to that extent. There are no reasons to disbelieve their statements. In the case of Sunil Kumar Sambhudayal Gupta & Others Vs. State of Maharashtra (2010) 13 SCC 657, the Hon'ble Apex Court has held that :-

"While appreciating the evidence, the court has to take into consideration whether the contradictions/omissions had been of 12 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 suchmagnitude that they may materially affect the trial. Minor contradictions, inconsistencies, embellishments or improvements on trivial matters without effecting the core of the prosecution case should not be made a ground to reject the evidence in its entirety. The trial court, after going through the entire evidence, must form an opinion about the credibility of the witnesses and the appellate Court in normal course would not be justified in reviewing the same again without justifiable reasons."

(22) Learned counsel for the appellants/accused also submitted that the deceased had received injuries in a tractor trolley accident, but this argument has no force because the deceased has received total 23 injuries which were caused by sharp cutting objects, therefore, it is not possible that these injuries can be received in an accident. (23) The appellants had not taken a plea of alibi in their examination recorded under Section 313 of Cr.P.C, therefore, the statements of defence witnesses has no value.

(24) Having considered the entire evidence available on record, we do not find any merit in the arguments advanced by learned counsel for the appellants/accused that the charges leveled against the appellants have not been proved beyond reasonable doubt.

(25) On the basis of the aforesaid discussion, there is no substance in the Criminal Appeal No. 540/2000 filed by the appellants/accused. Consequently, the same is hereby dismissed. The judgment of conviction passed by the trial court is hereby affirmed.

(26) So far as Criminal Appeal No. 389/2001 is concerned, we find that eye witnesses Bharat Singh (PW-

1), Chandrabhan (PW-2), Mantha (PW-3), Ram Singh (PW-

4) & Omprakash (PW-5) have stated that respondents 13 Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 Naktoo, Kamal @ Kamalpuri, Pintu @ Dineshprui & Prahlad have caused injuries to the deceased by saraia, but as per PM report, total 23 injuries have been found on various parts of the body of the deceased and out of them only one injury was found to be caused by the hard and blunt object which can be inflicted by the back portion of gandasi or farsa. In this regard the trial Court has appreciated the evidence in Paras 62 & 63 of the impugned judgment and discussed each and every aspect of the involvement of respondents elaborately, therefore, it is not possible to hold that the respondents/accused were present during the offence and they shared common object to murder the deceased, therefore, the trial Court has rightly acquitted the respondents.

(27) We have been taken through the entire record by the Public Prosecutor, we do not find any ground on the basis of which we may reach the conclusion that any of the finding recorded by the court below is improbable or does not require affirmation regarding acquittal of the respondents/accused.

(28) It is the settled law that the High Court would not ordinarily interfere with the order of acquittal unless the approach of the lower appellate Court is vitiated by some manifest illegality. Merely, because two views are possible, the High Court would not disturb the finding of acquittal recorded by the lower appellate Court as held in the decision of State of M.P. Vs. Ramcharan & Others, 1985 MPLJ 714.

(29) On the basis of the aforesaid discussion, there is no substance in the Criminal Appeal No. 389/2001 filed by the State. Consequently, the same is hereby dismissed. The judgment passed by the trial court is hereby affirmed.

14

Criminal Appeal Nos. 540/2000 & 389/2001 (30) It appears that Bharatpuri, Vidyapuri, Kalyan, Mahesh & Kishanpuri, the appellants of Criminal Appeal No.540/2000 are on bail. Their bail bonds are now canceled. They are directed to surrender before the trial Court without any delay so that they may be sent for execution of remaining part of their jail sentence. (31) The respondents Naktoo @ Narayanpuri, Kamal @ Kamalpuri, Rameshpuri, Pintu @ Dineshprui & Prahlad are also on bail. Their presence is no more required before this Court and, therefore, it is directed that their bail bonds shall stand discharged.

(32) A copy of the judgment be also sent to the trial Court along with its record for information and necessary action. 

              (Sanjay Yadav)                      (S.K.Awasthi)
